question.name: GenesByOldAnnotation
question.summary: Find genes with annotation changes since the previous release of @PROJECT_ID@.
question.description:
Find genes with annotation changes since the previous release of @PROJECT_ID@.

As research reveals new gene structure and function, many genomes are actively curated with annotation changes. This search returns genes whose annotations have changed since the last @PROJECT_ID@ release.

Use the default parameter settings (Don't Care) to return genes with at least one annotation change. Change the parameter settings to Yes or No to require that genes returned by the search either include or exclude changes in the Product Name, Coding Sequence, GO Functions or EC Numbers.

question.name: GenesByRodentMalariaPhenotype
question.summary: Find genes in which gene modifications lead to phenotypic changes at different lifecycle stages in rodent malaria.
question.description: Find genes in which gene modifications by mutation or disruption lead to phenotypic changes in the parasite at different lifecycle stages in rodent malaria.

question.name: GenesByLocation
question.summary: Find genes within a given genomic region.
question.description:
Find genes that are located in a specified region of a specified genomic sequence such as a chromosome, scaffold or contig.
Select a genomic sequence from the pull-down menu and/or enter a genomic sequence ID from any of the available species. If you supply both, your result will include the union. The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the gene(s) on the chromosome.

Find genes that are located within a specified genomic region. The search returns all genes found within your specified genomic location.

Enter the genomic sequence ID for the contig or chromosome that you want to query for genes. Example genomic sequence IDs are: %%defaultGenomeList%%.

Define the boundaries of the genomic location by entering the Start and End nucleotide coordinates of your region. Choosing Start=1 and End=0 will retrieve all genes on the entire genomic sequence.

Find genes that are located within a specified genomic region. Use either the Chromosome Tab or Sequence ID Tab to define the genomic location you wish to query. The search returns all genes found within your specified genomic location.

Chromosome Tab:
First select the Organism and Chromosome that you want to query. Then indicate the boundaries of the genomic location by entering the Start and End nucleotide coordinates of your region. Choosing Start=1 and End=0 will retrieve all genes on the chromosome.

Sequence ID Tab:
First enter the Genomic Sequence ID of the contig or chromosome that you want to query. Example genomic sequence IDs are: %%defaultGenomeList%%. Then indicate the boundaries of the genomic location by entering the Start and End nucleotide coordinates of your region. Choosing Start=1 and End=0 will retrieve all genes on the genomic sequence.

question.name: GenesByGeneType
question.summary: Find genes that encode a specific type of gene product such as protein, tRNA or snoRNA encoding genes.
question.description:
Find genes that encode a specific type of gene product such as protein, tRNA or snoRNA encoding genes.
You may choose to search for more than one gene type at once. Use the "Include Pseudogenes" parameter to further specify the type of protein coding gene you are looking for.

This search queries annotations. Not all gene types are annotated for each genome. Please hover over the 'Gene type' parameter help icon for a table of gene types available for each EuPathDB component site.

Find genes that encode a specific type of gene product such as protein, tRNA or snoRNA encoding genes.
You may choose to search for more than one gene type at once. Use the "Include Pseudogenes" parameter to further specify the type of protein coding gene you want to retrieve.

This search queries annotations. Not all gene types are annotated for each genome. Please hover over the 'Gene type' parameter help icon for a table of gene types available for each EuPathDB component site.

question.name: GenesByPhenotype
question.summary: Find T. brucei genes whose interruption (e.g. RNAi knockdown) resulted in a particular phenotype.
question.description: Find T. brucei genes based on the phenotype exhibited by modified parasites in RNAi knockdown and insufficiency studies. The phenotype results of RNAi experiments are curated from the literature by GeneDB.

question.name: GenesWithUpdatedAnnotation
question.summary: Find genes whose annotation at GeneDB is more current than the annotation in this release of @PROJECT_ID@.
question.description:
Find genes whose annotation at GeneDB is more current than the annotation in this release of @PROJECT_ID@.

@PROJECT_ID@ updates its data once per release cycle. GeneDB updates may occur more often than that. Genes returned by this search have updates applied by GeneDB that are not in this release of @PROJECT_ID@. The GeneDB updates will be included in a future release of @PROJECT_ID@.

The GeneDB annotation changes for genes returned by this search can be viewed by clicking the View updated annotation at GeneDB link that appears on @PROJECT_ID@ gene pages under the gene product description.

question.name: GenesByExonCount
question.summary: Find genes that have exons numbering within a range that you specify.
question.description: Find genes that have exons numbering within a range that you specify.

question.name: GenesByIsoelectricPoint

attributesList.sorting: primary_key asc,organism asc,isoelectric_point asc, gene_location_text asc

question.summary: Find genes whose protein products have an isoelectric point within a range that you specify.
question.description: Find genes whose protein products have an isoelectric point within a range that you specify.

question.name: GenesByMolecularWeight
question.summary: Find genes whose unmodified protein product has a molecular weight within a range that you specify.
question.description:
Find genes whose unmodified protein product has a molecular weight within a range that you specify.

Molecular weights are machine calculated from the raw translation and do not take into account any protein or residue modifications. For translations containing ambiguous amino acid codes (B, Z, X) the calculation uses the average of the upper and lower bound of the molecular weight.

question.name: GenesBySecondaryStructure
question.summary: Find genes whose proteins are predicted to have secondary-structure content (coil, strand or helix) that you specify.
question.description:
Find genes whose proteins are predicted to have the amount of secondary-structure content (coil, strand or helix) that you specify.

The secondary-structure content is predicted by the PSIPRED program. The percent composition is computed by counting the amino acids in which one of the three calls (coil, strand or helix) is given the highest confidence, and dividing by the length of the protein. For example, a protein's percent helix content is the number of amino acids in which a helix call has the highest confidence, divided by the length of the protein.

Reference:
Jones DT. (1999) Protein secondary structure prediction
based on position-specific scoring matrices
J Mol Biol. 1999 Sep 17;292(2):195-202

question.name: GenesByEcNumber

plugin.name: wordCloud
plugin.description: Display the terms in the attribute as word clouds

question.summary: Find genes that have been annotated as enzymes, i.e, that have been assigned an Enzyme Commission (EC) number.
question.description:
Find genes that have been annotated as enzymes, i.e. that have been assigned an Enzyme Commission (EC) number.

Enzyme Commission numbers describe enzymes hierarchically by the class of reactions they catalyze. For help with obtaining EC numbers, try the ExPASy-ENZYME browser.

First select the Organism(s) you wish to query. The search will return genes from these organisms. Then choose the Source of Assignment. integrated EC numbers from several sources. EC assignments from more than one source may be queried in a single search. Genes returned by the search will have EC assignements from the Source that you select here.

Next indicate the EC Number or Term you wish to query. Begin typing an EC number or name to see a list of all possible EC categories that match what you have typed. Then choose an EC category from the list.

Alternatively, you can type in EC numbers or descriptions. You can use '-' or '*' in place of numbers to denote partial EC Numbers, for example, '2.7.7.-'. or *kinase*

question.name: GenesBySnps
question.summary: Find genes that have SNPs and a specified SNP class, non-synonymous/synonymous SNP ratio and/or SNP density.
question.description:
Find genes that have Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs) and a specified SNP class, non-synonymous/synonymous SNP ratio and/or SNP density.

Note: This search has three numeric filters (count per class, ratio and density). Each takes two parameters. To disable a filter use the range 0-blank. (Blank is interpreted as infinity.) This range is the default, so by default the filters are disabled, and the search returns all genes that contain SNPs between the selected reference and comparator strains.

Note: Due to the extreme codon bias in the P. falciparum genome, the ratio of non-synonymous to synonymous SNPs per gene is much higher than expected. Please consider this when choosing parameters.

columnAttribute.name: num_nonsense
columnAttribute.help: SNPs where one or more variants encodes a stop coding

question.name: GenesByNgsSnps
question.summary: Find genes which have SNPs generated by HTS sequencing meeting specific criteria (Non-synonymous / synonymous SNP ratio, SNP density, etc).
question.description:
Search for genes by SNP density, the number of SNPs of different classes, ratio of non-synonymous to synonymous, etc. Note that if you do not care about one of the parameters, don't change the defaults on that parameter and you will get all genes irrespective of that parameter. For example, running this search to compare 3D7 and Dd2 using default parameters returns 2577 genes. Among the top 20 on the list are CLAG, AMA1, chloroquine resistance marker and multiple PfEMP1 and SURFIN genes.

Note: Due to the extreme codon bias in the falciparum genome, the ratio of non-synonymous to synonymous snps per gene is much higher than expected so this should be considered when creating queries. We are intending to calculate more reliable normalized Dn/Ds or Ka/Ks ratios in subsequent releases of PlasmoDB.

Search for genes by SNP density, the number of SNPs of different classes, ratio of non-synonymous to synonymous, etc. Note that if you don't care about one of the parameters, don't change the defaults on that parameter and you will get all genes that contain SNPs between the reference and comparator strains irrespective of that parameter.

columnAttribute.name: num_nonsense
columnAttribute.help: SNPs where one or more variants encodes a stop coding

propertyList.name: organism
propertyList.value: P. falciparum, T gondii, C. parvum

question.name: GenesByMassSpec
question.summary: Find genes that have evidence for protein-level expression from mass specrtometry-based proteomics experiments.
question.description:
Find genes that have evidence for protein-level expression from mass specrtometry-based proteomics experiments.

@PROJECT_ID@ maps peptides from proteomics experiments to a reference genome and allows you to search for genes based on that mapping. Expand the Experiment/Samples parameter to see a list of proteomics datasets integrated into @PROJECT_ID@. The list is organized by:

  1. the organism that the peptides are mapped to
  2. the experiment name (model organism)
  3. the samples analyzed in the experiment
The stringency of the search can be adjusted using the "Minimum Number of Unique Peptide Sequences" and "Minimum Number of Spectra".
Minimum Number of Unique Peptide Sequences:
Use this parameter to define the number of peptides that must map to a gene before the gene is returned by the search. Although protein expression is confirmed with the mapping of one unique pepetide, requiring more than one peptide to map to a gene will ensure that false positives are not returned by the search.

Minimum Number of Spectra:
Use this parameter to define the number of spectra that support a peptide before it is considered as evidence for expression of a gene. The total number of spectra that match a peptide to a particular protein is an indirect measure of the protein abundance.

question.name: GenesWithEpitopes

attributesList.sorting: organism asc,gene_location_text desc, count desc, confidence asc

question.summary: Find genes whose protein products are predicted to contain epitopes identified by the Immune Epitope Database and Analysis Resource (IEDB).
question.description:
Find genes whose protein products show similarity to an epitope identified by the Immune Epitope Database and Analysis Resource (IEDB).

Epitopes are antigenic determinants recognized by the immune system's antibodies, B-cells or T-cells. The epitopes from the original Epitope Source Accession Number provided by IEDB are mapped to the corresponding gene identifiers in @PROJECT_ID@.

Epitope sequences are mapped to genes in EuPathDB using exact string matching or high quality BLAST similarity (percent identity >= 97%) between the GenBank proteins listed on IEDB and the proteins found in @PROJECT_ID@. Confidence levels are assigned to each set of epitopes based on the quality of this mapping.

question.name: GenesBySimilarity
question.summary: Find genes that have BLAST similarity to your input sequence.
question.description:
Find genes that have BLAST similarity to your input sequence.

As of 3 Feb 2014, this search uses NCBI-BLAST to determine sequence similarity. Prior versions of the search used WU-BLAST. See the NCBI-BLAST help for more information.

First use the Target Data Type parameter to indicate the type of sequence (protein, transcript, genomic, etc.) that your Input Sequence should be BLASTed against. Then choose a BLAST Program to query your Input Sequence with and the Organism (genome) to use in your query.

Paste one Input Sequence in the text box. Only one sequence up to 31 Kb can be searched.

Default settings are indicated for the Expectation value, Maximum descriptions/alignments (V=B), and low complexity filter parameters.

BLAST Programs:
blastp compares an amino acid Input Sequence against a protein sequence database;
blastn compares a nucleotide Input Sequence against a nucleotide sequence database;
blastx compares the six-frame conceptual translation products of a nucleotide Input Sequence (both strands) against a protein sequence database;
tblastn compares a protein Input Sequence against a nucleotide sequence database dynamically translated in all six reading frames (both strands);
tblastx compares the six-frame translations of a nucleotide Input Sequence against the six-frame translations of a nucleotide sequence database.

question.name: GenesByMotifSearch
question.summary: Find genes whose protein product contains a motif pattern that you specify.
question.description:
Find genes whose protein product contains a motif pattern that you specify.
First choose the Organism that you wish to query. Then define the Pattern to query by entering a Perl style regular expression that defines the motif you want to find. Regular expressions are more powerful than PROSITE patterns.

For example, "CC6+RK" is a Perl style regular expression representing "two cysteines followed by one or more hydrophobic amino acids, followed by arginine and then lysine". The pattern need not be well conserved.

Another example is the pattern of the Pexel motif, which can be represented as "R.L.[EQD]", meaning "an arginine, then any amino acid, then a leucine, then any amino acid, then either an aspartic acid, a glutamic acid, or a glutamine".

For a description of how to create regular expressions, please see the Regular Expression Tutorial.

The following codes can be used to represent classes of amino acids.
AA property Amino acids Code
Acidic DE 0
Alcohol ST 1
Aliphatic ILV 2
Aromatic FHWY 3
Basic KRH 4
Charged DEHKR 5
Hydrophobic AVILMFYW 6
Hydrophilic KRHDENQ 7
Polar CDEHKNQRST 8
Small ACDGNPSTV 9
Tiny AGS B
Turnlike ACDEGHKNQRST Z
Any ACDEFGHIKLM
NPQRSTVWY 		.

question.name: GenesByInterproDomain
question.summary: Find genes containing a specified protein domain from the InterPro database.
question.description:
Find genes whose predicted protein contains a domain from the InterPro set of domain databases.

First choose the Organism(s) and Domain Database that you wish to query.

Then use either the 'Domain' or the 'Domain wildcard search' parameter to indicate the protein domain you wish to find.

When using the 'Specific Domain (s)' parameter, begin typing a domain name, accession or description, to see a list of all possible domains that match what you have typed. Then choose a domain name from the list. You can choose multiple domains using CTRL- or CMD-click when choosing the domains.

When using the 'Free Text (use'*' for wildcard)' parameter, type the text term you wish to find, including an asterisk wildcard for ambiguous portions of your text term. (*ase, kin*, *kinase*) The search will query for all domains whose names, accessions or descriptions contain your text.

The domain matches to protein sequence are determined using the InterProScan program. To learn more about InterPro see the InterPro tutorial.

Domain Databases
InterPro Database
Pfam Database    (Pfam families)
PRINTS Database
ProDom Database
PROSITE Database
SMART Database
SUPERFAMILY Database
TIGRFAMS Database

question.name: GenesByGoTerm

plugin.name: wordCloud
plugin.description: Display the terms in the attribute as word clouds

question.summary: Find genes based on the Gene Ontology (GO) Term(s) or ID(s) assigned to them.
question.description:
Find genes based on the Gene Ontology (GO) Term(s) or ID(s) assigned to them. GO annotations were either provided by the sequencing and annotation centers or inferred based on similarity to protein domains from the InterPro databases.

The Gene Ontology standardizes the representation of gene and gene product attributes across species and databases. The ontologies are a controlled vocabulary of terms for describing the molecular function, biological process and subcellular location of a gene product. This search returns genes with the GO Term or ID that you specify, as well as genes with terms that are specializations of your term (is-a). You may use '*' as a wild card character. For a list of GO terms, try the AmiGO browser.

When using the 'GO Term or GO ID' parameter, begin typing a GO Term or ID see a list of all possible GO categories that match what you have typed. Then choose a GO category from the list. You can choose multiple domains using CTRL- or CMD-click when choosing the domains.

When using the 'Free Text (use'*' for wildcard)' parameter, type the text term you wish to find and include an asterisk wildcard for ambiguous portions of your text term. (*ase, kin*, *kinase*) The search will query for all terms or IDs whose names, accessions or descriptions contain your text.

question.name: GenesByMetabolicPathway
question.summary: Find genes involved in a selected metabolic pathway from KEGG or BioCyc.
question.description: Find genes involved in a selected metabolic pathway from KEGG or BioCyc.
Find genes involved in a selected metabolic pathway from KEGG or BioCyc.

question.name: GenesByMetabolicPathwayIDKegg
question.summary: Find genes involved in a specific metabolic pathway ID.

question.name: GenesByMetabolicPathwayHagai
question.summary: Find genes involved in a specific metabolic pathway.
question.description:
Find genes involved in a specific metabolic pathway.

Maps of Metabolic Pathways were constructed as described on the Malaria Parasite Metabolic Pathways website here .
Metabolic Pathway Reconstruction for T. gondii is available on the KEGG Pathway site here.

Find genes involved in a specific metabolic pathway (Malaria Parasite Metabolism Pathways - MPMP)

Maps of Metabolic Pathways were constructed as described on the Malaria Parasite Metabolic Pathways website here .

Find genes involved in a specific metabolic pathway.

Metabolic Pathway Reconstruction for T. gondii is available on the KEGG Pathway site here.

question.name: GenesByReactionCompounds
question.summary: Find genes or enzymes that catalyse reactions in a metabolic pathway.
question.description: Find genes or enzymes that catalyse reactions in a metabolic pathway.

question.name: GenesByTransmembraneDomains
question.summary: Find genes whose protein products are predicted to have transmembrane domains numbering within a range that you specify.
question.description:
Find genes whose protein products are predicted to have the number of transmembrane domains within a range that you specify.

Transmembrane domains were predicted using TMHMM2.

question.name: GenesWithSignalPeptide
question.summary: Find genes that are predicted to encode a secretory signal peptide containing protein.
question.description:
Find genes that are predicted to encode a secretory signal peptide.

The predictions are made with the SignalP program.

question.name: GenesByOrthologPattern
question.summary: Find genes that have an orthology-based phylogenetic profile that you specify.
question.description:
Find genes that have a specified orthology-based phylogenetic profile. The phylogenetic profile of a gene is a series of "present" or "absent" calls, reflecting the inclusion of a gene in ortholog groups determined by the OrthoMCL algorithm.

The OrthoMCL algorithm clusters proteins into ortholog groups based on BLAST similarity across at least 150 genomes that span the tree of life. The ortholog groups document protein similarity across many species. Mapping ortholog groups onto the phyletic tree of life provides a framework for correlating protein similarity across species. The other species that are included in that gene's ortholog group can be thought of as a phylogenetic profile.

Use this search to define a pattern across those ortholog groups, and find genes that match that pattern. The pattern is a specification, for each species, of "include", "exclude", or "no constraints." Click on the radio button next to a species to toggle through the three states. A means "include", an means "exclude" and means "no constraints".

For example, to find genes that are present in Apicomplexa but not in humans, click on Apicomplexa until you see a and click on Homo sapiens until you see an .

question.name: GeneByTranscriptID
question.summary: Find a gene by transcript ID.
question.description: Find a gene by the ID of one of its transcripts.

question.name: GeneBySingleLocusTag
question.summary: Find a gene by its ID.
question.description: Find a gene by its ID. The search is case insensitive. Asterisks can be used as wild cards (e.g. ' PF11_* '). Genes whose IDs have changed can be found by either old or new ID. GI numbers (e.g. 23508535), Entrez Protein Locus IDs (e.g. NP_701204.1), PDB IDs (e.g. 1HN6), or GenBank IDs (e.g. AAB36701.1) can also be used.

question.name: GeneByLocusTag
question.summary: Find a gene by its ID.
question.description:
Find genes based on Gene ID(s).

Enter one or more gene ID(s) manually, or upload a plain text file containing a list of IDs. IDs can be delimited by a comma, semi colon, or any white space. For example, a list can be in the following form: "NCU06658, NCU06659, Ndisc8579_106685".

The IDs you provide cannot contain wild cards. Use the "Gene ID" quick search at the top of the page to search for genes using a partial ID completed with an asterisk wild card.

Find genes based on Gene ID(s).

Enter one or more gene ID(s) manually, or upload a plain text file containing a list of IDs. IDs can be delimited by a comma, semi colon, or any white space. For example, a list can be in the following form: %%defaultGeneList%%.

The IDs you provide cannot contain wild cards. Use the "Gene ID" quick search at the top of the page to search for genes using a partial ID completed with an asterisk wild card.

It is possible that not all IDs in the list will be found in the database due to annotation changes or unavailable ID mapping. At present we do not have a mechanism to inform you which IDs from your input did not match anything in the database.

question.name: GeneByLocusTag
question.summary: Find a gene by its ID.
question.description:
Find genes based on Gene ID(s).

Enter one or more gene ID(s) manually, or upload a plain text file containing a list of IDs. IDs can be delimited by a comma, semi colon, or any white space. The list can contain IDs from any annotated genome integrated into any EuPathDB component site. For a list of example Gene IDs use this strategy that returns all organisms integrated into EuPathDB and click the link in the Total Gene Count column of the organism you are interested in.

The IDs you provide cannot contain wild cards. Use the "Gene ID" quick search at the top of the page to search for genes using a partial ID completed with an asterisk wild card.

It is possible that not all IDs in the list will be found in the database due to annotation changes or unavailable ID mapping. At present we do not have a mechanism to inform you which IDs from your input did not match anything in the database.

question.name: GenesByTextSearch
question.summary: Find genes with a text search against their product name, notes, GO, EC, Domains, NRDB, or metabolic pathways.
question.description:
Find genes by searching text annotations. The search compares your term against the text in the fields you specify, returning genes that have a match.

Select the Organism(s) you wish to query and enter your text term. Surround your text term with quotation marks to find exact phrase matches. For example, searching "ABC transporter" will match the exact phrase 'ABC transporter', whereas searching ABC transporter will match ABC and/or transporter. Use an asterisk (*) as a wild card character when looking for plural or compound words. For example, to find all compound words that start with phospho (ie. phosphodiesterase), type phospho* in the search window.

Hints: The search is similar to Google -- if you enter multiple words, genes that match more of those words will have a better score than those that match fewer of the words. If the words are found close together, that also improves the score. Higher scores appear at the top of your result list.

Note about non-relevant results: Depending on how you configure it, this text search may return "non-relevant" genes (false positives). The search mechanically matches the term you supply against the Fields that you choose. The presence of your term in that field does not necessarily mean that the term actually describes the gene. The term may be mentioned in that field for less relevant reasons. To work around this, please carefully choose the Fields you want to search, and then, before drawing any conclusions, review the reference to your term in all matched fields in the gene page to confirm the meaning of its mention. The "Gene product" field is the most stringent and is unlikely to return false positives.

question.name: GenesByTaxon
question.summary: Find all genes from one or more species/organism.
question.description: Find all genes from one or more species/organism.

question.name: GenesByBindingSiteFeature
question.summary: Find Genes which have a specified transcription factor binding site upstream or dowstream.
question.description:
Plasmodium falciparum transcription-factor binding sites - Manuel Llinas

The DNA sequence motifs bound by each ApiAP2 transcription factor were derived from protein binding microarray data using P. falciparum AP2 domains. Protein binding microarrays are non-organism specific and contain matches to all contiguous 10-mers at least once and non-palindromic 8-mers up to 32 times. The DNA motifs were determined using purified recombinant AP2 domains and the resulting position weight matrix for each AP2 domain was used to search upstream regions for significant matches. The AP2 domain that binds to each motif is indicated at the end of the gene ID. Binding sites are based on sequence matches only and have not been verified in vivo.
For further information, contact Manuel Llinas: manuel@princeton.edu

References:

Identification and genome-wide mapping of DNA binding specificities for the ApiAP2 family of regulators from the malaria parasite.Manuscript submitted. 2010 Campbell et al

Compact, universal DNA microarrays to comprehensively determine transcription-factor binding site specificities

The AP2 motifs were mapped to the genome using the algorithm described in the following paper: Identification of transcription factor binding sites in the human genome sequence
The P value is the probability that the binding site with that score would match at that position given the input DNA (intergenic and telomeric regions). For example, a P value of 1X10-4 means that you would find a good match every 10,000 base pairs on average on that strand.

columnAttribute.name: tfbs_count
columnAttribute.help: Number of binding sites in the selected upstream region of this gene

columnAttribute.name: tfbs_distance
columnAttribute.help: Number of base pairs from the transcript start of this gene

question.name: GenesByChIPchip
question.summary: Find genes with evidence for expression based on ChIP-chip peaks
question.description: Find all genes with evidence for expression based on ChIP-chip peaks.

question.name: GenesByESTOverlap
question.summary: Find genes with evidence of expression based on overlap with Expressed Sequence Tags (ESTs).
question.description:
Find genes with evidence of expression based on expressed sequence tags (ESTs). Genes returned by this search overlap with EST sequences from organism-specific EST libraries.

Select the EST Library(ies) that you want to query. Use the Advanced Parameters to specify more or less stringent EST overlap and alignment characteristics of genes returned by this search. Individual parameter help is available by hovering over the help icon that appears after the parameter name.

Visualize EST alignments for any gene by clicking on the "View in Genome Browser" link from a gene page and turning on the EST Alignments track from the Genome Browser's Select Tracks page.

Find C. muris and C. parvum genes that overlaps with an Expressed Sequence Tag (EST).

EST overlap with an annotated gene is a useful way to verify gene predictions. Ideally we would have EST sequences for each gene prediction, but this is not the case in Cryptosporidium . Useful lengths of sequence overlap between an EST sequence and a predicted gene sequence are usually 50nt or greater. C. muris and C. parvum ESTs were clustered against their respective genomes. The cluster consensus sequences are available via the graphical genome browser on the gene record pages. Genes from the MRC-LMB sequencing of chromosome 6 are not included at this time.

question.name: GenesByNonnuclearLocation
question.summary: Find genes that are encoded in a specified region of the non-nuclear genome.
question.description:
Find genes that are located in a specified region of the non-nuclear genome such as the apicoplast

Choose the Organism and Genomic Sequence you wish to query. Then define the boundaries of the genomic region that you want to search by entering the Start and End nucleotide coordinates of your region. Choosing Start=1 and End=0 will retrieve all genes on the genomic sequence.

The search returns all genes found within your specified genomic location.

question.name: GenesOrthologousToAGivenGene
question.summary: Find genes that have been identified by the OrthoMCL project as orthologous (or paralagous) to a given gene.
question.description: Find genes that have been identified by the OrthoMCL project as orthologous (or paralogous) to a given gene.

question.name: GenesByCentromereProximity
question.summary: Find genes within a given distance from an annotated centromere location.
question.description:
Find genes within a given distance of an annotated centromere location.

Choose the Organism and Chromosome that you wish to query. Define the genomic region to query by entering a Maximum Distance from Centromere. The search will query two genomic regions that are equal in size to your indicated Distance - one region on each side of the centromere. The search returns genes found within the two regions.

question.name: GenesByTelomereProximity
question.summary: Find genes within a given distance from the telomeres (start and end positions) of chromosomes.
question.description:
Find genes within a given distance from a telomere.

Because telomere sequences are repetitive, they are not included in genome sequences. This search uses the start and end positions of chromosomes as the location of telomeres. When defining parameters for this search, please take into account that the actual location of the telomere is near the end of the chromosome.

First, choose the Organism and Chromosome that you wish to query. Then, enter a Maximum Distance from Telomere. The search will query two genomic regions that are equal in size to your Maximum Distance - one region on each side of the chromosome. The search returns genes found within the two regions.

question.name: GenesByPdbSimilarity
question.summary: Find genes whose protein products have high BLAST similarity to a Protein Data Bank (PDB) structure.
question.description:
The Protein Data Bank (PDB) is a repository for the three-dimensional structural data of large biological molecules. This search returns genes whose protein products have a high BLAST similarity to proteins whose structures have been experimentally determined and deposited in the Protein Data Bank (PDB).

First specify one or more organisms whose genes you want to retrieve.

Then choose the clade of organism whose PDB records should be queried for BLAST similarity. Specify the cutoff for the p-value exponent for the BLAST similarity between the gene and the PDB structure.

question.name: GenesWithStructurePrediction
question.summary: Find P.f. genes that have computationally predicted 3D structure models.
question.description:
Find P. falciparum genes that have computationally predicted 3D structure models.

The models were generated computationally by Dinesh Gupta at the ICGEB. They are seeded with experimentally-determined structures of similar proteins (from PDB).

question.name: GenesWithUserComments
question.summary: Find genes about which user comments have been submitted.
question.description: Find genes about which user comments have been submitted.

question.name: GenesByProteinProteinInteraction

attributesList.sorting: times_observed desc, number_of_searches desc, gene_location_text asc
times_observed desc, number_of_searches desc, gene_location_text asc

question.summary: Find interacting partners of a specific gene as determined by yeast two-hybrid experiments.
question.description:
Find interacting partners of a specific gene as determined by yeast two-hybrid experiments. This data is available for P. falciparum only.

Gene ID
Enter the ID of the gene for which you want to find interaction partners. Genes returned by this search have protein products that were identified as interacting with the protein product of the Gene ID you enter here.

Number of searches that found this interaction
Indicate the number of independent yeast two-hybrid screens in which a given interaction was found before a gene (the interacting partner) is returned by the search. This parameter can also be considered "Times Reproduced". Interactions found in more than one yeast two-hybrid screen are more likely to be true positives because the data were independently produced.

Number of times this interaction was found Indicate the total number of times a given interaction was identified in all yeast two-hybrid screens before a gene (the interacting partner) is returned by the search. This parameter can also be considered "Times Observed".

An interaction can be identified multiple times in the same screen for several reasons (see 1-3 below) but only (3) provides independent confirmation of a putative interaction.
(1) The original yeast cell containing the pair of interacting proteins divided before being plated on selective media;
(2) The same prey plasmid was present in the library multiple times giving rise to multiple positive colonies;
(3) The prey gene was present in the library as multiple independent, overlapping fragments, all of which interact with a given bait.

Specified protein is bait or prey
Indicate whether the protein product of the Gene ID should be the bait (fused to the binding domain) or prey (fused to the activation domain) in the yeast two-hybrid experiment.

Find interacting partners of a specific gene as determined by yeast two-hybrid experiments. This data is available for S. cerevisiae only.

Gene ID
Enter the ID of the gene for which you want to find interaction partners. Genes returned by this search have protein products that were identified as interacting with the protein product of the Gene ID you enter here.

Number of searches that found this interaction
Indicate the number of independent yeast two-hybrid screens in which a given interaction was found before a gene (the interacting partner) is returned by the search. This parameter can also be considered "Times Reproduced". Interactions found in more than one yeast two-hybrid screen are more likely to be true positives because the data were independently produced.

Number of times this interaction was found Indicate the total number of times a given interaction was identified in all yeast two-hybrid screens before a gene (the interacting partner) is returned by the search. This parameter can also be considered "Times Observed".

An interaction can be identified multiple times in the same screen for several reasons (see 1-3 below) but only (3) provides independent confirmation of a putative interaction.
(1) The original yeast cell containing the pair of interacting proteins divided before being plated on selective media;
(2) The same prey plasmid was present in the library multiple times giving rise to multiple positive colonies;
(3) The prey gene was present in the library as multiple independent, overlapping fragments, all of which interact with a given bait.

Specified protein is bait or prey
Indicate whether the protein product of the Gene ID should be the bait (fused to the binding domain) or prey (fused to the activation domain) in the yeast two-hybrid experiment.

question.name: GenesByRtPcrFoldChange
question.displayName: C.p. post-infection semi-quantitative Real Time PCR (fold change)
question.summary: Find C. parvum genes that are differentially expressed between different time points based on expression profiles from high-throughput semi quantitative Real Time PCR (RT-PCR) experiment. Select a comparison and reference time point, fold induction and the direction of regulation.
question.description:
Find C. parvum genes that are differentially expressed between different time points based on expression profiles from high-throughput semi quantitative Real Time PCR (RT-PCR) experiment. Select a comparison and reference time point, fold induction and the direction of regulation.

Expression values at every time point for a gene were normalized to the corresponding expression value of 18s rRNA (see description below for a detailed explanation). Median expression value across the replicates was then computed at each time point for every gene. Expression values for every gene were then standradized to the highest value across time points (with the highest value = 1 and remaining time points scaled proportionally).

For further experiment details please refer the data sources listed below.

question.name: GenesByProfileSimilarity
question.summary: Find genes that have a similar expression profile to your input gene.
question.description: Find genes that have a (glass slide) expression profile similar to that of your input gene.

question.description: Find genes that have a (glass slide) expression profile similar to that of your input gene.

question.name: GenesByToxoProfileSimilarity
question.summary: Find genes that have a similar expression profile to your input gene.
question.description:
Find genes that have a cell cycle expression profile similar to that of your input gene.

The following links will load gene lists identified by Behnke et al. to be cell cycle regulated.

1. Cell Cycle Regulated Gene List, Both
2. Cell Cycle Regulated Gene List, G1 Sub Transcriptome
3. Cell Cycle Regulated Gene List, S-M Sub Transcriptome

The RHTK+ strain used in this analysis expresses a fusion protein of herpes simplex thymidine kinase and chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (Radke and White). Synchronization of RHTK+ parasites with thymidine followed published protocols (Radke and White). In this synchrony model parasites released from thymidine immediately progress through S, mitosis and then cytokinesis. The first G1 phase is the start of the next cycle. All time points represent microarray hybridization results from duplicate, independent biological replicates. Parasites were seeded at an MOI of 1:1 in HFF cells, and grown for 12 h at 37oC (4-8 parasites per vacuole). To block RHTK+ growth, overnight culture media was replaced with pre-warmed DMEM media containing 1% fetal bovine serum and 10 µM thymidine. The flasks were incubated for 4 h at 37oC and then quickly washed 2x with pre-warmed DMEM (no serum) with the second wash immediately replaced with pre-warmed DMEM media containing 1% serum (three total washes). RHTK+ parasites from multiple T175cm2 flasks (10-20 flasks per RNA sample) were purified from host cells for RNA isolation every hour post-thymidine release using standard protocols. R0 time point=thymidine blocked population. Asynchronous RHTK+ samples were harvested from mid-log cultures (8 and 16 parasites/vacuole). The R0-12 time course represents ~1-2/3 divisions with tachyzoite cell cycle phase repeats R1,R2=R8,R9, R3=R10, R4=R11, and R5=R12 (Behnke et al., 2010)

Figure 1. Synchronization of tachyzoite populations by reversible thymidine-inhibition. The average vacuole size (black boxes) and fraction of parasites containing internal daughters (black triangles) were determined in RHTK+ parasite cultures growth-inhibited by thymidine. At hour intervals through 12 h post-thymidine release, infected monolayers were fixed and stained with anti-IMC1. Vacuole size and the internal daughter fraction were determined in 100 vacuoles selected at random. The synchronous division of these populations is evident by the cyclical rise and fall of internal daughter forms that is accompanied by a stepwise increase in vacuole size that marks the end of one cycle and the start of the next. The cell cycle progression shown here was estimated from these experiments and is validated by previous studies using this synchrony model (Radke and White, Radke et al.).

Figure 2. DNA content changes of thymidine-synchronized populations. RHTK+ parasite cultures were blocked with 10 µM thymidine for 4 h and then released. At one hour intervals post thymidine-release (R0-R12), parasites were harvested and pooled for RNA isolation with a small sample removed for DNA content analysis prior to cell lysis. Genomic DNA in ethanol-fixed parasites was stained with SYTOX-Green and changes in DNA content determined by flow cytometry (FL-1; 10,000 events for each sample). As described previously (Radke and White), thymidine-arrested RHTK+ parasites are blocked at the G1/S phase boundary (R0) and immediately enter S phase upon drug-release (R1). New daughter parasites start emerging by 3 h post drug-release (R3), and the population enters the S phase of the next cell cycle by 7-8 h post-release. The cell cycle progression is indicated with cell cycle phase repeats R1,R2=R8,R9, R3=R10, R4=R11, and R5=R12 (C=cytokinesis, M=mitosis, G1=gap 1 phase, S=DNA synthesis).

question.name: GenesByEQTL_HaploGrpSimilarity
question.displayName: P.f. eQTL HB3-Dd2 cross (similarity of associations)
question.summary: Find P. falciparum genes that have associations (cis or trans) to any/all the regions associated with the entered gene based on eQTL experiments on HB3,Dd2 and progeny.
question.description:
Find P. falciparum genes that have associations (cis or trans) to any/all the regions associated with the entered gene based on eQTL experiments on HB3,Dd2 and progeny. This query first looks for regions associated to the entered gene within the LOD cut-off and then finds other genes (across the genome) that are associated to these regions.

Microsatellites were mapped to the genomic sequence to generate a physical map with coordinates for the haplotype blocks. Since the exact coordinate location of cross-over event is unknown, two sets of locations were generated for the boundary of each of the haplotype block. A Conservative estimate for the boundary of a haplotype block starts at the first microsatellite to map within the region and ends at the last microsatellite to map in the region. A Liberal estimate of the boundary starts at the end of the last microsatellite that was mapped in the previous haplotype block and ends at the beginning of the first microsatellite mapped in the next haplotype block.(Refer to the picture below for a graphical explanation HB=Haplotype Block).



In this study, genome-wide expression level polymorphisms (ELPs) were examined in a genetic cross between phenotypically distinct parasite clones of P. falciparum (HB3 and Dd2). Using cDNA microarray hybridizations from the progeny of a genetic cross, gene expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) were mapped in an experimental population of malaria parasites. Each gene's transcript level was used as a segregating phenotype to identify regions of the Plasmodium genome dictating transcriptional variation.

columnAttribute.name: cut_off_score
columnAttribute.displayName: Max LOD of Regions assoc to Input Gene

question.name: GenesByEQTL_Segments
question.displayName: P.f. eQTL HB3-Dd2 cross (association to genomic segments)
question.summary: Find P. falciparum genes that have associations (cis or trans) with any region in the chromosomal segment entered (whole region, or part of it) based on eQTL experiments on HB3, Dd2 and progeny.
question.description:
Find P. falciparum genes that have associations (cis or trans) with any region in the chromosomal segment entered (whole region, or part of it) based on eQTL experiments on HB3, Dd2 and progeny.

Microsatellites were mapped to the genomic sequence to generate a physical map with co-ordinates for the haplotype blocks. Since the exact co-ordinate location of cross-over event is unknown, two sets of locations were generated for the boundary of each of the haplotype block. A Conservative estimate for the boundary of a haplotype block starts at the first microsatellite to map within the region and ends at the last microsatellite to map in the region. A Liberal estimate of the boundary starts at the end of the last microsatellite that was mapped in the previous haplotype block and ends at the beginning of the first microsatellite mapped in the next haplotype block.(Refer to the picture below for a graphical explanation HB=Haplotype Block).



In this study, genome-wide expression level polymorphisms (ELPs) were examined in a genetic cross between phenotypically distinct parasite clones of P. falciparum (HB3 and Dd2). Using cDNA microarray hybridizations from the progeny of a genetic cross, gene expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) were mapped in an experimental population of malaria parasites. Each gene's transcript level was used as a segregating phenotype to identify regions of the Plasmodium genome dictating transcriptional variation.

question.name: GenesByExpressionPercentile
question.summary: Find genes expressed in early ring, late ring, early trophozoite, late trophozoite, early schizont, late schizont, merozoite, sporozoite, or gametocyte.
question.description:
Find genes expressed in early ring, late ring, early trophozoite, late trophozoite, early schizont, late schizont, merozoite, sporozoite, or gametocyte.

The data is from a total of 17 microarray experiments (1) performed using an Affymetrix short oligonucleotide platform. Cultures were synchronized using two independent methods, 5% D-sorbitol and temperature cycling, for all developmental stages except Gametocyte and Sporozoite. This platform contains oligos (25-mers) derived from the predicted coding regions of the entire P. falciparum genome.

Expression values for each probe set were obtained by the MOID algorithm (2). Queries can be performed to retrieve only those genes in at least the Xth percentile level, where X can be from 95 to 5. In this way it is possible to select only the most highly expressed genes, to any desired level above the 5th percentile. Genes are returned in decreasing order of their intensity.

However, please note that, regardless of the percentile expression level selected, only genes that are above background and whose observed expression level would not be expected by chance (MOID expression level >10 and logP < -0.5) are included and will be reported. This means that genes that have only a single probe on the array will not be reported as their logP values will always be too high to satisfy the query.

question.name: GenesBySubcellularLocalization
question.summary: Find genes whose protein products are likely targeted to the apicoplast or the RBC membrane.
question.description:
Find genes whose protein products are likely targeted to the apicoplast or the RBC membrane.

Transit peptides share specific amino acid characteristics and mediate protein targeting to the apicoplast. Set the Location parameter to Apicoplast to return genes whose protein products contain the amino acid characteristics of transit peptides that target proteins to the apicoplast.

Pexel and HT motifs are associated with parasite proteins that are targeted to the human erythrocyte membrane. Set the Location parameter to Pexel or HT to return genes whose protein products contain Pexel or HT motifs (respectively).

question.name: GenesByExportPrediction
question.summary: Find genes that are predicted by ExportPred to produce an exported protein.
question.description:
Find genes that are predicted by ExportPred to produce an exported protein.

The ExportPred algorithm uses a generalised hidden Markov model to model simultaneously the signal sequence and PEXEL motif features required for protein export. To read more about ExportPred please click here.

question.name: GenesByMr4Reagents
question.summary: Find genes that have available reagents.
question.description:
Find Plasmodium falciparum genes that have MR4 reagents.

The reagents are mapped to genes using gene names and GenBank/EMBL sequence similarity. An MR4 reagent may be linked to multiple genes when it is not clear which is the correct gene or if the reagent might be considered to function with either gene.
Find genes that have antibodies available from the Biodefense and Emerging Infections Research Resources Repository.

Find Plasmodium falciparum genes that have MR4 reagents. The reagents are mapped to genes using gene names and GenBank/EMBL sequence similarity. An MR4 reagent may be linked to multiple genes when it is not clear which is the correct gene or if the reagent might be considered to function with either gene.

Find Cryptosporidium parvum and Toxoplasma gondii genes that have antibodies available from the Biodefense and Emerging Infections Research Resources Repository.

question.name: GenesByPlasmoDbDataset
question.description: Find genes by importing a PlasmoDB 4.4 search result. The Query History page at the PlasmoDB version 4.4 site (http://plasmodb.org) now contains a column called "Dataset." To import any of the queries run at the PlasmoDB 4.4 site, cut and paste the Dataset identifier from the PlasmoDB Query History page.

question.name: GenesByCopyNumber

attributesList.summary: strain, raw_estimate, haploid_number, ref_cn, ploidy, gene_dose, gene_product, chromosome, orthomcl_link

question.summary: Find genes based on the number of copies in resequenced strains
question.description:
Find genes with a copy number in a resequenced strain that is within a range that you specify.

Whole genome resequencing data was used to estimate each gene's copy number in resequenced strains. This search returns genes that are present at copy numbers (haploid number or gene dose) within a range that you specify.

You have the choice between two different metrics for defining copy number: haploid number or gene dose. Haploid number is the number of genes on an individual chromosome. Gene dose is the total number of genes in an organism, accounting for copy number of the chromosome. For example, a single-copy gene in a diploid organism has a haploid number of 1 and a gene dose of 2.

Begin by choosing an Organism (reference genome) and a Resequenced Strain. Then choose your Metric, Operator and Copy Number, and initiate the search by clicking the GET ANSWER button. Genes returned by the search will have a copy number based on your chosen metric within the range that you specified. For example, searching with the haploid number equal to 4 will return genes with 4 copies on a chromosome.

columnAttribute.name: raw_estimate
columnAttribute.help: The number of copies of this gene in the resequenced isolate as calculated by the analysis pipeline. This metric is appropriate to use in a non-clonal population

columnAttribute.name: haploid_number
columnAttribute.help: An estimate of the number of copies of this gene on a single copy of the chromosome in the resequenced isolate obtain. This metric is a weighted rounding of the Calculated Copy Number

columnAttribute.name: ref_cn
columnAttribute.help: The number of genes in the reference annotation inferred to have arisen through the tandem duplication of a common ancestor of this gene. This is estimated as the number of genes that are both on the same chromosome and in the same ortholog group as the gene of interest

columnAttribute.name: ploidy
columnAttribute.help: The number of copies of the chromosome that this gene is on calculated by the analysis pipeline

columnAttribute.name: gene_dose
columnAttribute.help: An estimate of the total number of copies of the gene of interest in the resequenced isolate, accounting for the ploidy of the chromosome in that isolate

question.name: GenesByCopyNumberComparison

attributesList.summary: strain, raw_estimate, haploid_number, ref_cn, ploidy, gene_dose, gene_product, chromosome, orthomcl_link

question.summary: Find genes by comparing the gene copy number in the resequenced strain to its copy number in the reference genome.
question.description:
Find genes by comparing the gene copy number in the resequenced strain to its copy number in the reference genome.

Whole genome resequencing was used to estimate each gene's copy number in resequenced strains. This search compares the estimated copy number of a gene in the resequenced strain with the copy number in the reference annotation. The copy number in the reference annotation is calculated as the number of genes that are both on the same chromosome and in the same ortholog group as the gene of interest. We infer that these genes have arisen as a result of tandem duplication of a common ancestor.

In this search, the metric for copy number is the haploid number, which is the number of copies of a gene on a single chromosome.

Begin by choosing an Organism (reference genome), a Resequenced Strain, then choose how you want to compare the resequenced strain to the reference. You can search for genes where the estimated copy number in the resequenced strain is greater than or equal to, equal to, or less than or equal to the number of copies in the reference genome. Be cautious using the less than or equal to operator, because regions which do not sequence well may appear to have reductions in gene copy number.

columnAttribute.name: raw_estimate
columnAttribute.help: The number of copies of this gene in the resequenced isolate as calculated by the analysis pipeline. This metric is appropriate to use in a non-clonal population

columnAttribute.name: haploid_number
columnAttribute.help: An estimate of the number of copies of this gene on a single copy of the chromosome in the resequenced isolate obtain. This metric is a weighted rounding of the Calculated Copy Number

columnAttribute.name: ref_cn
columnAttribute.help: The number of genes in the reference annotation inferred to have arisen through the tandem duplication of a common ancestor of this gene. This is estimated as the number of genes that are both on the same chromosome and in the same ortholog group as the gene of interest

columnAttribute.name: ploidy
columnAttribute.help: The number of copies of the chromosome that this gene is on calculated by the analysis pipeline

columnAttribute.name: gene_dose
columnAttribute.help: An estimate of the total number of copies of the gene of interest in the resequenced isolate, accounting for the ploidy of the chromosome in that isolate

question.name: GenesByOrthologs
question.description:
Find the @PROJECT_ID@ genes that are orthologs (or paralogs) of the genes in a search result. The typical use of this query is to begin by having an interesting result in a strategy. Then, use this search to find orthologs of those genes in a species that may not be annotated with the data from your original result. In general, use this search to transform sets of genes from one species to others.

Ortholog groups were generated from more than 100 species using OrthoMCL as described in Li L, Stoeckert CJ Jr, Roos DS. OrthoMCL: identification of ortholog groups for eukaryotic genomes. Genome Res. 2003 13:2178-89. The OrthoMCL DB site is described in Chen F. Mackey AJ. Stoeckert CJ Jr. Roos DS. OrthoMCL-DB: querying a comprehensive multi-species collection of ortholog groups. NAR. 34(Database issue):D363-8.

question.name: GenesByWeightFilter
question.description: Filter away results that have a weight outside the specified range. (This transform is only useful if the input result sets have used weights)

question.description: Find all genes by organism

question.description: Find genes that are located in the specified genomic regions.
